results.title: Theremin: An Electronic Odyssey documentary poster
results.brief_description: Poster for the documentary ‘Theremin: An Electronic Odyssey.’ This documentary explores the life of Leon Theremin, the inventor of an electronic synthesizer called the theremin, which uses motion to produce a sliding ethereal sound. After creating the instrument, Theremin is kidnapped by the KGB to work on inventions and surveillance technology. During his absence, the theremin becomes a popular instrument in film scores and through the performances of Clara Rockmore. In 1991, Theremin finally returns to the United States after his release.

results.title: S*it rentals with Melvin
results.material_description: digital screen recording of @PurplePinger's TikTok stream
results.brief_description: With his ironic analysis of rental property listings, @PurplesPingers has become a symbol of Australia’s frustration with the housing crisis. Using just a smartphone and a deadpan delivery, the activist and lawyer dissects the misleading and exaggerated claims of property listings, exposing the shoddy practices of real estate agencies and the dodgy conditions renters face. His videos have received over 4.3m likes on TikTok, leading him to be comment on the crises on news and morning shows. Though conservative hosts can be combative, the activist maintains his ironic detachment, employing logic and the law to dismantle their arguments.
results.description: With his ironic analysis of rental property listings, @PurplesPingers has become a symbol of Australia’s frustration with the housing crisis. Using just a smartphone, screenshots and deadpan delivery, the activist and lawyer dissects misleading and exaggerated property listings, exposing the shoddy practices of real estate agencies and the dodgy conditions renters face. With over 4.3m likes on TikTok, he’s been invited to comment on the crisis on traditional media. Though conservative hosts can be combative, the activist maintains his wry detachment, using logic and the law to undermine their arguments.
description_for_label: With his ironic analysis of rental property listings, @PurplesPingers has become a symbol of Australia’s frustration with the housing crisis. Using just a smartphone, screenshots and deadpan delivery, the activist and lawyer dissects misleading and exaggerated property listings, exposing the shoddy practices of real estate agencies and the dodgy conditions renters face. With over 4.3m likes on TikTok, he’s been invited to comment on the crisis on traditional media. Though conservative hosts can be combative, the activist maintains his wry detachment, using logic and the law to undermine their arguments.

results.title: Remixing Julia Gillard's misogyny speech
results.brief_description: This video remixes former Prime Minister Julia Gillard’s iconic ‘Misogyny Speech’ with an early example of the common ‘get ready with me’ TikTok trend. User Minorfauna readies to go out while lip-synching the famous speech, which Gillard delivered during a parliamentary address after being labelled sexist by the opposition leader. By mixing the speech with a trend largely perceived to be led by women, Minorfauna takes aim at sexist and outdated assumptions about women – much like Gillard, whose iconic speech was voted the most unforgettable moment in Australian TV history by Guardian readers.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

This video remixes former Prime Minister Julia Gillard’s iconic ‘Misogyny Speech’ with an early example of the common ‘get ready with me’ TikTok trend. User Minorfauna readies to go out while lip-synching the famous speech, which Gillard delivered during a parliamentary address after being labelled sexist by the opposition leader. By mixing the speech with a trend largely perceived to be led by women, Minorfauna takes aim at sexist and outdated assumptions about women – much like Gillard, whose iconic speech was voted the most unforgettable moment in Australian TV history by Guardian readers.
description_for_label: This video remixes former Prime Minister Julia Gillard’s iconic ‘Misogyny Speech’ with an early example of the common ‘get ready with me’ TikTok trend. User Minorfauna readies to go out while lip-synching Gillard’s famous parliamentary address, delivered after being labelled sexist by the opposition leader. By mixing the speech with a trend largely perceived to be led by women, Minorfauna takes aim at sexist and outdated assumptions about women, using the #bosschallenge hashtag to connect Gillard’s explosive comeback to women’s everyday experiences.

results.title: Minyak Sawit Keluarga (Palm Oil Family)
results.brief_description: Minyak Sawit Keluarga (Palm Oil Family) by artist Olivia Koh, examines her paternal family’s history of farming practices in rural Southern Malaysia (Peninsula). Footage of domestic-scale palm oil plantations in Johor is interspersed with visual and auditory recordings of funerary Daoist rituals, documents and interviews that consider the palm oil industry and relevant history of migration in the local area.
results.description: Minyak Sawit Keluarga (Palm Oil Family) by artist Olivia Koh, examines her paternal family’s history of farming practices in rural Southern Malaysia (Peninsula). results.title: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
results.creator_credit: Marlene Rubuntja and Sally M Nangala Mulda
results.brief_description:
First Peoples were forcibly moved from their lands into designated camps by European colonists from around 1880 onwards. As a result of the ongoing displacement of First Peoples, Amoonguna was established as a government reserve 21kms from Mparntwe (Alice Springs) in 1963. Known as town camps today, reserves like Amoonguna make up the Alice Springs Aboriginal housing associations. These town camps are home to many artists who are extremely proud of their communities. English is often the third language of Amoonguna residents with the major language groups being Arrernte (pronounced Arenda), Warlpiri and Pitjantjatjara.

Mparntwe is a place where government policy and intervention in First Peoples communities has distinct and obvious implications. The Australian media often portrays this part of the nation negatively, without showing the historical narratives at play or the strength, beauty and talent that comes from the Central Desert. At the centre of the exhibition Two Girls From Amoonguna, is the animated video work Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls, which reminds audiences that Mparntwe is filled with joy and laughter. From camping and travelling to town to finding bush tucker, this place is home.

Tangentyere Artists and Yarrenyty Arltere Artists are akin to community hubs. Not only are they gallery and commercial spaces, but they are also places for young ones to learn and spaces for important community discussions.

For Sally M Nangala Mulda (Arrernte and Southern Luritja) and Marlene Rubuntja (Arrernte and Western Arrarnta), their art centres reflect their artistic practices. The soft sculpture, sewing and bush dyeing seen in Marlene’s works are synonymous with Yarrenyty Arltere Artists. Tangentyere artists like Sally are renowned for figurative paintings, which are often autobiographical and depict scenes in and around Mparntwe. These centres provide culturally safe places for artists and community. With the success of both artists, they have become prominent figures in their communities and teach many young people within their kinship structure. Intergenerational knowledge sharing is integral to First Peoples’ ways of life – you can even hear the voices of the artists’ nieces and nephews in the animated work.

Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls was made in collaboration with Ludo Studio, the Emmy-award winning production company behind Bluey, Robbie Hood and The Strange Chores. It is the third ACMI + Artbank Commission.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Marlene Rubuntja and Sally M Nangala Mulda
results.description:
Life in the Central Desert can be challenging, but it can also be breathtakingly beautiful. Two Girls From Amoonguna tells the intertwined story of Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja, from their childhood years to now as two of Australia’s leading artists, through paintings, sculptures and a newly commissioned animated video.

The animation Arrkutja Tharra, Kunkga Kutjara, Two Girls was inspired by a conversation between Sally and Marlene, held on the steps of the Sydney Opera House, where they reminisced about their shared childhood at the Amoonguna settlement, outside of Mparntwe (Alice Springs), in the early 1960s. Figures from Marlene’s soft sculptures and Sally’s acrylic-on-linen paintings come to
life, depicting life as they know it to create a portrait of two friends and the communities that made them.

Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls was made in collaboration with Ludo Studio, the Emmy-award winning production company behind Bluey, Robbie Hood and The Strange Chores. It is the third ACMI + Artbank Commission.
description_for_label:
